none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from L. J. Storey, May 28, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from L. J. Storey, May 28, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 19 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
W. Strickland & Co. Lith. Galveston.

Office of
Nix, Storey & [illegible]orey
Attorneys & Counsellors at Law,
AND LAND AGENTS.

[Margin: Jonathan Nix.
L. J. Storey.
A. B. Storey.]

Lockhart, Texas May 28th 1885

Prof L L McInnis
College Station Tex
Dr Sir, We want a
good man to put at the head
of our School here, a man
who is able to build up a good
School We have a good house
and about 150 to 175 Students
If you know of any Competent
person tell them We are ready
to Contract with such a person
Please do me the favor to reply
Yours &c
L. J. Storey

**Analyzing this letter is proving to be quite the exercise!** I'm looking at this handwritten letter and trying to piece together every detail. It's addressed to Professor L.L. McInnis at College Station, Texas – a known figure. The letterhead is from Nix, Storey & Storey, Attorneys & Counsellors at Law, in Lockhart, Texas, and I'm noting the fine details like the lithography firm's name tucked away in the top left corner: W. Strickland & Co. Lith. Galveston. The date is May 28th, 1885.

I'm starting to transcribe the text, and there's this recurring visual issue. The writer’s capital "W" often looks like an "M". However, the context is clear. "We" makes the only sense, so I'm rendering it as intended. The writer is asking Professor McInnis if he knows of a "good man" to lead their school. It appears they have a good facility and around 150-175 students. The letter is requesting that if McInnis knows "of any Competent person tell them We are ready to Contract with such a person, Please do me the favor to reply". It's a standard business request of that era. I’m confirming each word and scanning for ambiguous characters, especially at the end of lines or words, where the handwriting gets a bit rushed. The signature at the end is L.J. Storey, which matches the printed name on the letterhead.

The format is traditional for the era. The date is placed below the letterhead, and the body of the letter is indented. The letter includes formal language and standard abbreviations, like "Dr Sir" for "Dear Sir", and "Yours &c". Even with a tear in the paper obscuring part of the header, I’m reconstructing what's legible. The transcription is ready!
